justification: The article notes that “One such measure is the evaluative priming task, developed by Fazio and colleagues (1986)… implicit attitude measures, which are used to capture valenced associations that people may not be consciously aware of.”

It states that “Warriner and colleagues (2013) asked participants to rate the valence of words on a scale of 1 (very unpleasant) to 9 (very pleasant) and found that participants assigned the word ‘cause’ a valence rating of 5.13.”
The text explains that “Linguistic Inquiry and Word Count (LIWC), a tool that researchers use to measure qualities of written text, identifies ‘cause’ as a cognitive verb that lacks valence.”
